That said, I still give Via Veneto 4 stars. I know it's been a Boyfriend Family favorite (or at least Frequent) for some time and the little food I was able to force down and keep in was quite good. In fact, writing this has me jonesing for a repeat visit. The service is gracious, the prices are very reasonable, and everything from the appetizers to entrees to desserts was well presented. I just love the frilly, girly low-lit interior (this is the antithesis of hip and your mother will love it). Wine list is decent and markups aren't over the top. For a restaurant on Fillmore, this place has a lot going for it. The chances that I will up my rating to 5 stars after I actually eat more here is good.
author: Autumn K.

description:
From the first time we set foot inside Via Veneto - we felt like we'd been going for years. Massimo (the host & owner) always greeted us with a big smile. No matter how long it had been - he treated us like royalty.

We read a few reviews that this place had an "old" crowd ... what exactly does that mean? It's not hoping with loud music and drinking rowdies? Fine by me! 

We definitely wouldn't describe the atmosphere as old ... more fresh and romantic. They have fun painting on the walls of birds & cherubs playing with pasta. The colors are light and airy. It's lovely.

There's also not the pretentiousness of many of the restaurants in that area. You can wear jeans and a tshirt and receive the same level of service as if you were in a tux. We actually went there every year we lived there for Valentines Day. And when we made our "reservations" early and Massimo forgot ... he made room for us even when they were overbooked. Gotta love that!

The food is amazing of course. It's not the BEST italian food in the world -- but it's definitely up there in the top 5. Being fish-eating vegetarians - we were always impressed with their fish of the day selection and their raviolis (esp the lobster). 

Good food ... good service ... BELLISSIMO!
author: Tabitha R.

description:
Food was good.  I got the ravioli of the day, a mushroom one with "Italian bacon" and tomatoes and a light cream sauce.  The calamari salad was fine, although there was some extra taste in the dressing that made it not so good.  Desserts looked good - at least one person said, "this is really good ice cream."  And the half carafe of wine was pretty huge...three people had some, and there was still some left over.

However, the service was slow, slow, SLOW.  

AND, I asked for decaf coffee, yet I'm sitting here reviewing this place at 1:41am...coincidence?  I think not.
author: Kerrie L.

description: Quite possibly the best Artichoke ravioli I have ever had in my life...and the Tiramisu was excellent!!
author: Rachel N.

description: This is a great place. Cute inside and out. The staff are friendly and the atmosphere is calm and inviting. Food has been fantastic.
author: Molly M.

description:
Totally decent. 

A non-pretentious spot on Fillmore. Pasta dishes run around $11-13. Pasta is a good 'al dente', but the sauces (we tried the Gnocchi Florentine and Penne all' Amatriciana) left a little to be desired. Good, but just lacked that quality that made me want to eat more. 

I was happy to run across Via Veneto on a cold foggy day in the Fillmore, but I'm not sure I would go out of my way to get there again.
author: Erin M.

description:
There is nothing really special about this place. I can't say it was bad, but it was just kind of boring. It didn't help that the service was pretty slow, and not very streamlined. 

I don't know... I'm over paying inflated prices for mediocre Italian food by people who think they are better than I am. If I wanted that I'd just go have Persian food. At least those people speak my language.
author: Jason R.

description:
Bottom line - not very good. 
Not bad, but not good. 
Gnocchi was NOT homemade, it was the same mushy, tasteless stuff you can buy at Safeway. And, it was overcooked with a bland sauce.

I moved back to SF in April and living in Pacific Heights I have passed by Via Veneto several times. A few weeks back I walked in with my partner on a Saturday night at 9pm and was asked if I had reservations. It never occurred to me to make reservations at what seems like a neighborhood Italian joint, so we promptly left smirking and went to Jitlada for Thai. Last night we decided to try Via Veneto again since the bridge was closed for Labor Day and I figured they would be hurting for business. 

It was empty. We were promptly seated by an unfriendly older waiter who spoke Italian to another older man. First thought - they're speaking Italian, this is going to be good.

Wrong. It was bland and unremarkable. The minestrone soup was decent, not great. The gnocchi was obviously not homemade and was over cooked. My little Italian grandmother made the world's best gnocchi, so I am something of a snob when it comes to this dish, but I expect it to be at least homemade and it should be firm, not mush. My partner had the mussels appetizer which was very fresh and the pasta puttanesca which was overly salty and a very small portion.

Half a carafe of wine for 12 dollars was a good deal, but I would not recommend this restaurant and will not go back. We should have gone to Jitlada again last night.
author: Marcia B.

description:
The minute you enter Via Veneto you feel like you have been transported to Italy. The environment is chatty, the staff is friendly and the food is simply delicious. 

The first time I walked by the place, I just stop to practice my rusty italian with the owner. I didn't even eat there, just stopped to talk and my experience was so nice that the following week I went back to eat. 

A week later, I just stopped for a glass of wine with my Italian friends. It turned into appetizers and later into a full meal. Later I took my mom, an Italian food snob, and she loved it too.

Opposite to most comments, my service has always been speedy, although I admit that they are not rushing it as they are more concerned about making you feel right at home.

What to eat? The capresse salad and bruschetta are a good way to start.  The penne matriciana is amazing. The sword fish in a wine/lemon/caper sauce is to die for. The pasta with boar ragu is strong and tasty. But as Massimo pointed out, their specialty is the fish, so make sure to order one of the many seafood options.

As a tip, their house red wine is outstanding and you can order it by the half or full carafe. And yes, the pear dessert is as unforgettable as everybody says.

In conclusion, the service is like in Italy, if you demand it, you'll get it. The feeling is local, you will find a lot of regulars (me included) and the food is authentic and fairly price. If you are looking for a quiet place where to catch a bite before a movie, go somewhere else. But if you want authentic Italian food in a low key lively environment, you won't be disappointed at Via Veneto.
author: Gabriela P.

description:
There's no substitute for a friendly Italian owner.  He always goes out of his way to make sure every guest is having a superb time in his restaurant.  The food is great too. I've had something different every time I've been there and I've never been disappointed. 

And if you want to embarrass a birthday girl or boy, this is certainly the place to take him/her.  You'll have to go in and find out what happens for yourself, but just trust me on this.
author: Zoe K.

description:
So its a Friday night and i'm feeling like some Indian food, and since i live in the Mission, my first thought is Dosa, and being that it is Friday the wait is an hour. I was willingly to wait the hour, i mean its valencia st and there are a millions things to do to past the time, but my friends thought otherwise. 

Now we had to decide what we wanted to eat, so we spent 20mins sitting in the car debating where we should go next. If we had put ourselves on the waiting list at Dosa we could have been 20mins closer to eating at Dosa!

So we decided to head to the fillmore/pacific heights area, we parked and began our walk up fillmore street. Everyone was hungry and indecisive so i made an executive decision, the first place i saw that i thought would be good, and then i saw this place, looked pretty nice, wasn't too crowded and but it wasn't dead, and the wait....was non-existent.

My thoughts at first were..hmm...thats funny the cook is winking his eye at me and blowing me a kiss...i should be flattered..strangely i don't think i was, but moving on.

We were seated at this table in a corner but i was nice, my friend, Nicole and i said we felt like we were in a buffet at a vegas hotel because of the paintings on the wall. The Waiter was cool, not great, the owner was much cooler. It did surprise me though that they didn't have garlic bread, but maybe that just an americanized idea of Italian, that they all should serve garlic bread. We did however get some wonderful french bread.......hmm...with garlic and oil...so i guess thats kind of Italian.

Anyway we order our food i order the Chicken Marasala, with this very tasty spinach and i hate spinach,but i loved that spinach, could it be it was drenched in garlic..i love garlic...so anything drenched in garlic, is a winner for me. My friend whom ordered the same thing wasn't the biggest fan. My other friend wayne got some oysters or mussels , something that had shells and he was not impressed,so i don't know if i would recommend those. 

So as we are eating and in a walks a very strange looking made in a black trench coat, and all the sudden, i feel like i did when i first walked in the cook blew me a kiss,and winked at me, that feeling very-uneasy.And thats when the owner walked up to the table and any uneasiness i felt disappeared! 

The owner makes you feel as though you are right home with his family back in his native Italy. He greets us with a grand hello in his thick Italy accent and a huge smile, He joked with us and was so grateful that we are there. 

I thought the food was good, but not exceptional, the service was ok,and the wait for a check was pretty long, the desert wasn't very good. I'm big on customer service so when the owner themselves comes to your table to greet its always a plus. True i would have preferred Dosa but i'm glad i checked this place out, i can't say  i'll be very soon, but i can say i will return at some point if i'm in that neighborhood.

I'll just hope the cook doesn't recognize me, if and when i do return. There is just something about the cook blowing a kiss and winking at you that makes you feel like you are at a cafe in the middle of nowhere, in one of those campy b-movies where the teenagers get stranded.
author: Nia W.

description:
It's never a good sign when you spend most of your time chuckling in an incredulous fashion.  We were seated, but then it took about 10 minutes for anyone to notice us.  Odd, since the place was only about a quarter full and there were two waiters who were just wandering around the restaurant, doing nothing at all.  After we finally got seated, I noticed that pretty much everyone in the place was drunk, including some of the staff! Solo patrons downing a bottle of wine each, a drunk woman going in and out of the restaurant with a full, then less full wine glass and then conversing loudly with those seated near her.  The owner seemed kinda sauced as well, amusing.  Between ordering and receiving appetizers, the staffer who seated us asked if we'd like dessert menus.. haha...what?  

I'm not a restauranteur, but I don't think that spaghetti + 4 shrimp + a little olive oil, black pepper, and rosemary should cost 15 bucks unless it's amazing.  And this dish was among the most amateur looking and tasting items I've ever had in any restaurant.  Pile o'bland, oily noodles, 4 overcooked shrimp, room temperature.  My girlfriend's chicken was pretty sub-par as well, and the vegetables accompanying the dish were a joke straight out of your grocer's frozen foods aisle.  Decided to spare them of any more of my money, got the hell out at that point.  If cousin Tony from Italy visits, I'd rather take him to the Olive Garden.  Che peccato!
author: Karthi X.

description:
Via Veneto has been here for years; It doesn't have the buzz of SPQR, the foodie street cred of Vivande or the cult status of Jackson Fillmore. It doesn't have the hippest, coolest decor.

What Via Veneto DOES have is consistently good food in the Northern Italian vein. Great appetizers (including a yummy fried calamari), delicious pastas and secondi. The desserts are especially good -- profiteroles, poached pears with ice cream and fruit sauce.

Last time I ate here, it was a Friday night impromptu dinner for five. We got in easily when there was at least an hour wait at the restaurants noted above. I'm glad we didn't get into the other ones. We had a long, leisurely dinner with two bottles of wine, and almost closed the place down. No pressure to get up so they can turn a table.
author: Gary B.

description:
I had a very romantic and tasty dinner at Via Veneto the other night. I had tried to get in over at SPQR, but was not prepared to wait an hour and a half, so off we went looking for a place to eat. We walked in and were quickly greeted and shown to a table in the front. The place is pretty small, so the tables are close, but everyone around us appeared to be having a great dinner.
We started with the spinach salad and it was great. We ordered one to share, and two huge plates came to our table. The wine list was also very nice and reasonable. For dinner, I had the Chicken Marsala and my husband had the veal. Both were excellent and I was very happy with both the price and the portion. We did not have room for dessert this time, but I will be back!!
author: Lisa A.

description:
Shockingly bad food.  The minestrone soup was undercooked and no aromatics were used in the prep. Watery Tomato  base and an over abundance of carrots thrown in for color made for a sharp acid base overlaid with a cloying sweetness-got to wonder how this place stays in business. Surprising that such a mediocre (at best) restaurant  could survive in such an upscale neighborhood-Alas,  all that money and no taste. I ordered the  scaloppini (another Italian classic) but their version swam in a thick greasy gravy that was sharpened  by caper brine.
The coffee was so bad as to be undrinkable.
author: Ann P.

description:
I work right up the street and I used to eat here at least once a week. It got rather boring until they open up the patio in the Summer months. The menu could use a revision. There is not too much on it besides pasta. Where is the scallopini or piccata?

The staff is attentive and sometimes gives you a few Bruschettas on the house. 

It is still cold out so I think it will be a few months until I return to Via Veneto.
author: Jeannine V.

description:
My favorite Italian place by my house. Every time I ate there,  I had to be rolled out. The owner is always warm, welcoming and hooks us up with free bruschetta. The best appetizer is the eggplant with mozzarella. All my friends who have been fortunate to dine with me here have loved it. We also enjoyed the carpaccio. The Cesar salad portion is huge and  could be shared by two to three people.

My favorite pasta dish is the linguine with clams. I don't recall the names of the other dishes my friends have had, but they were all very good.Last time we were there, the special ravioli was raved by the customers sitting at the bar. We usually get great recommendations on wine pairings with our pasta and my friend visiting from NY loved one so much, she wrote it down to purchase. At the end of our meal, we were served a shot of limoncello. It tasted like lemon vodka.

Overall, this is my "IT" place if I am too lazy to travel for Italian. On a warm day, you can sit in the back patio, drink wine, and relax with your friends. It's laid back, the service is great, and the food is excellent.
author: Sophie C.

description:
Went here on a fluke with a couple of girlfriends.  The waiters were very welcoming when we walked in.  We decided to split a few dishes since we couldn't make up our minds.  

To start we had the caprese and another type of tomato salad.  The caprese salad was a little bland but the other salad was excellent. They even brought it out on individual plates already split for us. 

Entree wise we had the gnocchi with the cream sauce which was really tasty and we also shared the prawn spaghetti which was good and loaded with garlic.   

They were even so kind when my friend knocked over her water glass.   Nothing that they couldn't throw a little salt on....which was interesting.

Not an extensive wine list, but there were some decent choices.  It was a good experience, and good food.  I would go back again!
author: Shelley B.

description: I have always liked this spot since moving to Pac Heights and have been a few times.  My favorite is definitely the gnocchi alla sorrentina.. it is baked with a tasty tomato sauce.  They had a sea bass special last week which was amazingly juicy.  Don't you think that I didn't have the chocolate gelato last visit because that would just be silly.  It is good, but nothing close to the gelato found in Italia.. I don't know what it is.. the cream.. the water.. the feeling I get in Italy.. just not the same.
author: Gregg K.

description: Love this place. I've eaten there four times and each time had delicious food and exceptional service.  A little upscale without any sticker shock - beats a two-bus dinner in north beach easily.
author: Jwl s.

description:
I enjoy coming to this place for its ambiance and savory food.  Every dish I have ordered here has tasted superb, and the servers are all affable.  It hosts an intimate setting and there is rarely a wait.   If you're looking for a pleasant place to dine, with authentic food and without a crowd and exorbitant prices, visit Via Veneto.  

Divertiti!
author: Alexa G.

description:
After living in Pacific Heights for 7 years we finally were able to get a table after seeing a movie.  

It is a nice place.  The hostess was very engaging.  The waiter was attentive.  We enjoyed the ambiance.  

The food was quite good.  Loved the garlic and olive oil mix that came with the bread.  The veal marsala was different than I have ever had but quite tasty.  The fish was delicious according to my husband.  

Definitely worth a try.  Most of the time you will need reservations.
author: Karen B.

description: After seeing "Black Swan" Saturday evening at the Kabuki, my husband and I thought we'd hang around Fillmore for a meal instead of heading to a favorite spot. We walked up Fillmore and all the usual places were packed---Delfina Pizza, SPQR--even the lesser places too. We're not 25 anymore so we wanted less of a scene. On we walked until hitting Via Veneto. Yeah, it looked a little cheesy from the street but we tried it anyway. Nice Caeser salad, very good Pinot Noir ofr $8 and my mushroom ravioli with asparagus and other veggies was good too. Was it the best pasta I've ever eaten? No. But I hate going to places where you feel totally ripped off by high prices or disappointed that the meal was not at all adequate. This was a very comfortable place to be, the other customers seemed quite happy too, and some I noticed were regulars.
author: M F.

description:
I must add that Massimo's minestrone is a lifesaver if you're feeling under the weather like the rest of SF'ers.  Come here for speedy recovery and excellent convo w/my man Massimo.
=====================================================
I've been eating here since I was 12.   Every time I go to Via Veneto I feel like I'm home.  Massimo is my man....I call and within 10 minutes take-out for 10 is ready.

I am not a big dessert person...in fact I hate chocolate....but I love the poached pear!  I cannot put in words how incredible it is.  The balance of the pear poached in cinnamon, filled with mascarpone (okay it may be whipped cream) and raspberry coulee (how do you spell that?) is perfection.

I always start with the insalata via veneto, which is like a light Greek salad, and follow with chicken milanese or veal picata.  

The food is consistently good.  Having eaten here over a hundred times I can vouch for this.  Don't come here expecting a Michelin experience, but take it for what it is...a good neighborhood restaurant.  Oh yeah, and it's right across the street from the Clay Street theater.
author: debbie h.

description:
I've been here a couple times now. The food's pretty good, and they have a decent wine selection. The house wine is pretty good too.

Standard-issue caprese -- nothing to write home about. I've tried the gnocchi in white sauce -- creamy and pretty filling; porcini mushroom ravioli (I think it was a special?); one of my friends tried the chicken in marsala sauce. End with some tiramisu and some coffee. Good.

Everyone enjoyed their meals.

Nothing really stands out, but I still like this place. I'd go back again. Helps that Massimo is quite the Italian host.
author: Premshree P.

description: I love Via Veneto! This restaurant looks beautiful both inside and outside. I can feel Italian atmosphere. Also, I love customer services here. The food is nice too.
author: Palmy L.

description:
My parents were visiting a couple of weeks ago and we were in pacific heights hoping to get a last minute table at Fresca.  After being told we couldn't get in until 10 there, we were literally picked off the street by the manager of Via Vento.  I took this as a bad sign, but my dad was starving so we decided to give it a go.  

If i had to describe this place in a word, I'd go with bland.  I was not impressed by the decor (far too white and bright).  The food was all okay, but not great or even really good.  There were 5 of us so we ordered a variety of dishes but almost everything tasted like we could have thrown it together ourselves for a fraction of the cost.  My boyfriend's alfredo was worse that most grocery store jar pasta sauce I've had.  

Would I tell people to avoid it?  Probably not.  But for the cost I'd say there are probably 100 better places to eat in the city.
author: Katie S.

description:
I love this place... 
The food is excellent! the prices are high, but it is worthy. 
Also, really nice place. I felt comfortable inside (I usually do not like fancy places). 
The service was also good.
author: jaime b.

description:
Service: very friendly and attentive
Decor: a little strange but ok.
Food: completely unmemorable.  Not bad at all, but I really do not remember what I ate.  I do remember thinking it was average as I ate it.  I guess if you live in the neighborhood and really don't feel like cooking this may be the mid-week place for you.  Another one of our neighborhood restaurants that is sadly under-whelming.
author: Nilu r.

description:
Ate here after the Jazz Festival, I thought it was a cute little place, very sunny and nice atmosphere. The service was prompt, but I wouldn't say particularly friendly. My husband and I are a little younger and were dressed fairly casually plus we didn't feel like an appetizer or wine so that might have added to the lack of loquaciousness (alliteration is fun).

The food was okay. It was definitely not bad, but it could have been better. However, the prices were really good so I would probably come back for the atmosphere.
author: Katy W.

description: A girlfriend & I had dinner last week at Via Veneto.  It is great to see this restaurant still around in the Fillmore District, especially since the rest of the area has become so expensive. Food, atmosphere & service is still excellent!  Big plus still reasonably priced for the amount, quality of food you receive. The hostess greeted us right away.  The server came with very nice focaccia w/balsamic & vinegar dip. We both had the grilled chicken breast which consisted of 2 perfectly done breasts on top of sautéed spinach, & with roasted potatoes. For dessert we ordered 2 wonderful cream desserts:  One was a chocolate ball that consisted of a layer of chocolate cream & gelato that had a sponge cake center, surrounded by a dark chocolate sauce & sliced strawberries.  The second was a wedge of vanilla gelato that had candied fruit &  chocolate bits in it, coated with dark chocolate, & a layer of vanilla cream also surrounded by the dark chocolate & strawberries.  We look forward to going again; only next time in warm weather so we can enjoy the beautiful outdoor patio.
author: Pam R.

description:
We stopped into Via Veneto on a Monday night (perhaps not the wisest choice as that can often be the head chef's night off).  The restaurant is bathed in white and is very appealing both from the street and once you enter.  The menu is pretty standard italian fare and our dishes weren't very good.  Ron had a tortellini dish where the sauce was wayyyyyy too heavy, bordering on dry and the who things was pretty flavorless too.  Liz's pasta dish was bland and uneventful.  Staff seemed a bit disconnected and only really warmed up when it was time to take the check.  The fact that this really seems to be a neighborhood restaurant may explain some of the disconnection, but that said, it's still important to turn out a good product and Via Veneto just missed on all counts.  The best thing we had were the biscotti served with our check.
Bummer.   -Ron & Liz
author: Ron T.

description:
The flavors are right on. They have one of my top 5 appetizers ever- the eggplant mozzarella! 

Service is slow, yet I would say tryyyyy it.
author: Lee M.

description:
I've been here three times and each time I've been very happy with my food. 

 My boyfriend and I randomly went last night as we were in the area and I was craving pasta with tomato sauce.  I don't remember the name of what I had, but it was fettuccine with tomato sauce, eggplant and ricotta salata.  It was exactly the flavor I was craving and I was totally satiated.  

My boyfriend ordered the meat ravioli with tomato cream sauce, ham and peas.  He loved it and so did it.  Think: Pasta wrapped in bacon.  It's a beautiful thing. 

We both ordered a really good pinot by the glass, but then lamented the fact that we didn't get a bottle, since we drank many glasses of it.
I read other reviews that said the service wasn't good.  All the times that I've been the service has been impeccable.  The bus boys, the server even the owner came by to check on us. 

The Clay Theater is across the street, so it seems like a good place for dinner and movie.
author: Kim S.

description:
My first meal in SF in several years was at this restaurant with my good friend a couple weekends ago.  It's rather small and intimate, but you don't really notice so much.  

Yes, the place is romantical, but it was also a little noisy, which I like because it gives me carte blanch to raise my voice.  I had the veal, which was delish and well-proportioned to my hunger.
author: Khurram N.

description:
i'm bumping up one star!  was here for a friend's bday dinner.  they actually stopped the music for the entire restaurant to play a festive happy birthday song as they brought out a candle and dessert for my friend.  

we all felt very special at that moment  :)
author: Sammi C.

description: They start you off with a complimentary bruschetta topped with a garlicky onion tomato basil mixture on a slightly grilled round of bread..I think it was the best part of the meal. Nice and not very memorable salad. Very good bread  on the table with delicious fruity olive oil for dipping. OK ravioli stuffed with porcini mushrooms. I took most of it home and enjoyed it more the next day. Enjoyed the glass of verdicchio. Nice host.
author: Bleep S.

description:
Massimo is a fun host.   He's a character, very italian, very gracious.  Relax and enjoy your stay.  He raised his voice at some rude, arrogant customer's which was very much in character.  Service isn't quick, but it's kind of like being in Italy.

Good food and wine.
author: Berne F.

description: True Italian. The food has always been amazing and it's been my best friend's and my "default" restaurant for over a year now. My girlfriend is really picky and they are always very sweet in accommodating her requests and always get it right. I highly recommend the carpaccio, the brusectta and all of their pastas. This is the place to go if you want a nice long dining experience the Italian way. If you're not a diner and you're trying eat and leave relatively quickly then this is not the place for you. I am not a diner myself but I found it very relaxing and enjoyable to embrace the Italian dining experience.
author: D K.

description: For a place that *should* reek of authenticity, "V-squared" really disappointed me. A buddy of mine thinks it is the greatest place ever, but I was really underwhelmed -- not only with my entree but also by the painfully slow service. It's not like the restaurant was crowded or anything, so I still can't figure out why that old cat who reminds me of Geppetto couldn't be more attentive. I might give them another try someday, but it's probably gonna take some serious 'Eye-talian' coaxing.
author: Gregor G.

description: This is a good overall Italian Restaurant.  The ambiance was a bit bright, but I looked at the plates of food on tables and it looked great.  The food was very good, and the portions just right.  The prices were also very good.  If I lived here, I'd come back.  It's on a nice part of Fillmore, easy to get to and a nice overall experience.
author: Chris S.

description: I loved this place.  We were almost not going to go but there really isn't anything around Fillmore so we checked this place out (thankfully so).  The owner was very cool in fitting us in san reservation.  Service was excellent and our dishes were great.  I would definitely go back.
author: Kirsten M.

description: Really cute little neighborhood spot.  They had a lot of options on the menu that were very reasonably priced.  I ordered a pasta and my boyfriend ordered the risotto of the day -- both were very good and filled with lots of seafood.  Am also a big fan of the house montepulciano -- a half carafe is only $12 -- great deal!
author: Mitzi C.

description: I have been going to Via Veneto (emphasis on FIRST syllable, not middle one) for many years. I continue to be impressed and satisfied with the class, quality and service of this restaurant. The owner/main waiter/sometimes bartender moves quickly through the ample dining room and bar, and the other person at the bar helps on the floor when needed. The food is wonderful. Last night, I had the special-salmon and halibut, with mixed vegetables and potatoes. The fish was poached and so tender and perfectly cooked. Although I've had the tiramisu on other occasions there, I passed on dessert this time around as I was contentedly full. My partner requested a dish not on the menu, which was a sort of variation of a dish on the menu. The owner/waiter was happy to accomodate, which is unusual in restaurants. I had a couple of glasses of wonderful Italian Barbera with my dinner, and my partner had the Chianti, both very nice representatives of the varietals they are made from. All in all, a fantastic experience which I am recommending to you for your pleasure. Located up on Fillmore Street across from the Clay Theatre, it's easy to get to as well.
author: daniel k.

description: 3.5 stars, actually.  Food was pretty good.  I thoroughly enjoyed my tortellini.  The stuffed mushroom appetizer kind of had an odd flavor to it.  I was expecting a more garlic-butter flavor.  My chocolate gelato was HUGE and it was delicious!  The atmosphere is pleasant, and the owner was really warm and gracious.
author: Eileen H.

description: I've been back to this place a few more times since my last review and I would like to bump them up to 4 stars because every time we've been there the food has been quite good but I just can't seem to bring myself to because the thing is...which is very off-putting to me...the waiter (same one every time) is so obviously inattentive to us and I'm not sure why! We're nice people! We're not hideous to look at! Yes, we have come in the company of an older person who uses a walker every time we've been there and no, we don't drink a lot of alcoholic beverages but hey, it's lunch hour and the place isn't exactly hopping... I recommend to the owner or manager to talk to his staff to learn some simple manners and that will take him and his business a long way!
author: Mimi W.

description:
Great neighborhood joint. We've been going for years. Good place to feed your craving for some hearty italian food. My faves are the seafood pastas - all tasty. The meat dishes are full of flavor and usually cooked to perfection - try the veal picatta or pork chop special.
The service is friendly and accommodating, with a personal touch if you're a regular.
Love the wine suggestions from the owner.
author: Kimmie N.

description: Picture this - a warm, sunny back patio, coffee, omelet and marscapone-stuffed french toast.  I spent Sunday brunch on the tiny but pretty back patio at Via and had a wonderful time.  We arrived right as it opened, so things were a bit chaotic (no menus, had to ask for napkins), but the waiter and owner were both so warm and friendly it wasn't a big deal.  As mentioned by other reviewers, the owner takes a personal interest in your comfort and satisfaction.  The coffee was good, the food was nice (if a bit bland - my omelet needed salt) and the service was the best.  The price was nice, too, with our party averaging $12-13 for entree and coffee.  There's no people watching, but if you want a nice meal in relaxing (i.e. you don't have to shout to your seatmates) surroundings, try Via next Sunday.
author: Suzanne B.

description: When my husband and I lived in Pac Heights, it took us a while to go to Via Veneto.  It always looked fancy, and we rarely saw young people dining.  I'm so glad we tried it one night. It's our favorite Italian restaurant now.  The staff is so friendly, we rarely have to wait for a table, and the food couldn't be better.  Some of our favorites are: Scallopini Saltimbocca, Tortellini, Gnocchi (cream sauce), and Torta di Gelato al Cafe (coffee cheesecake).  I'm getting hungry just thinking about it.  This is some serious comfort food.  Nothing like a great neighborhood restaurant.
author: angela t.

description: We were hoping to find a neighborhood haunt but were disappointed by the mediocre food. Service was adequate, slow to start but definitely more attentive towards the end. Unfortunately, it could not make up for the food. 2 stars only for the beef carpaccio and piping hot linguine pescadore. They got the temperature right on the pasta but the seafood was lackluster,  mussels tasted kinda bad so I  was too afraid to finish them.  Calamari was chewy and and consisted of only the 'rings'--i.e. frozen disaster. My search for great neighborhood Italian goes on...
author: Linda Y.

description:
After reading all the reviews, had high hopes. Ambience was nice and the service was excellent. Our waiter was very helpful and let us all 3 of us taste multiple wines before ordering a bottle.

The entrees, unfortunately, were not impressive. My friend's penne was *extremely* salty. My grilled salmon was totally bland, served with zero seasoning and some veggies / potatoes... and my gf's lobster ravioli was OK.

Despite the below average entrees, we decided to gamble on dessert. I'm glad we did. The crepe with vanilla ice cream and espresso sauce was great as was the Tiramisu.

Really wanted to like this place, but the entrees were just not up to par. Despite that, I think I'd actually give this place another chance... I'm hoping that we just had bad luck on our choices. We'll see.
author: Nithin R.

description: The food is consistent here, but nothing that blew my mind so that I would even remember what I ate.  It is nice inside if you get a window seat, but I find the atmosphere very bland.  Also, the tables are so tightly packed you can hear all the conversations around you- and they can hear yours.  This isn't too big a deal, unless your companion is having some issues and starts repeating the same conversation like 6 times.  For serious, I was wondering if the lady was on medication.
author: CAKE E.

description: Very good Italian and reasonably priced.  Jared was pretty much spot on with his review.  The owner/manager definitely takes a hands-on approach to making sure everyone is happy - he could be seen pacing all over the restaurant with a watchful eye.  I had a linguine w/seafood dish which was excellent.  My friend had calamari in a rich tomato sauce and that was very good as well.  The bruschetta was well done...I hate oily or too-garlicy bruschetta and this was just right.  We were there early in the evening so it was pretty empty but I have seen the place fill up.  The atmosphere was great.  A good place to take a gf or parents when you want to have a nice but not expensive dinner.  I have to give 5 stars because of the value.
author: Dave M.

description: When we moved to Pac Heights we stumbled on Via Veneto quickly and we instantly knew this would be our new go-to dinner spot. The ambiance is light and sunny and very very friendly. The owner and wait-staff remember everyone in the neighborhood and they are always excited to see you and joke around with you. The food is amazing and the pasta always tastes incredibly fresh and well made. I have never been disappointed.
author: Meg M.

description: There's a reason Via Veneto is relatively empty around dinner time on Saturday nights. The prices are decent for Fillmore Street, but I've had much better food and the service is painful. It's one thing to allow conversation and flow, but it's another for me to have to stare you down for 20 minutes in order to get something ordered when there are only 4 other groups in the restaurant.
author: Chris B.

description: We came here one night with a group, we were all hungry. I can remember it taking a while for our table to get ready but then came the food and all was forgotten. This is such a delicious place. If you like authentic Italian food, you'll like this place!
author: Alexandra D.

description:
You know, I saw one reviewer say service at Via Veneto is painfully slow.  I would have to disagree because I've been at this restaurant three times, including last night.  I find the service pretty good, even during busy times.   

I've had Gnocchi before and it's seriously tasty with the melted cheese that comes with it.  Also, you should save enough room for dessert and try the strawberry ice cream cheesecake with white chocolate.  I  don't remember how it's labeled on the menu but you will see it and it's to die for.  I don't recall ever having a more interesting dessert in a long time.  Just the thought of combining ice cream and cheesecake.  That's delicious.  :)

I will admit Via Veneto does have a typically older crowd so it may not be the most hip and romantic place in the world but it's well-organized, at a nice location and has pretty good food.
author: M B.

description: Via veneto was sloppy seconds.  We originally wanted to go to the Fillmore Grill, but apparently it's now closed.  So, Via Veneto it was.  Italian food is always good, right?  Wrong.  They burned the garlic in my friend's dinner and it tasted gross.  My salmon risotto made me sick.  The service was so so.  All in all it was a disappointing meal.
author: Michelle L.

description: We are new in town and we are looking for good places to eat. We read the reviews in yelp and we were not dissapointed. The food was excellent and the service was good too. This place was what we were looking for. A small, quiet place were we could feel almost at home. The prices was also right. We willbe back!!
author: Sandra F.

description: Came here for lunch with a group of friends. I got the gnocchi Florentine. It was really good. Good potions too. The waiter was really nice but a little on the slow side. All the other dishes looked really delicious too.. Can't wait to go back to try them.
author: Juliane N.

description: I've been here twice.  Once for lunch and once for dinner.  By chance, I took my wife here for her birthday dinner.  We like Via Veneto and will be back again.  The food is good to very good, the service is fast and very friendly, the prices reasonable.  If you're looking for an above average Italian restaurant, give Via Veneto a try.  You'll be glad you did.
author: Brad P.

description: Ok, this is more of a 3.7 review so I rounded up. The food was very good- my gnocchi was excellent, and my Italian grandmother was famous for her's so I'm picky.  Large portions and a reasonably priced wine list. The service was very slow, but the management handled it well- free brushchetta and port. I was definitely a happy camper.
author: Noelle Q.

description: First time at Via Veneto although I've wondered about it and walked past it for years.  I had a really lovely evening. The service was relaxed and friendly.  The food was very good (I had fettuccini alfredo and my partner had gnocchi.)  About half way through our meal a fellow picked up a guitar and started belting out Italian songs in the front of the house.  That was fun, though I'm glad I was in the back where I could still carry on a conversation. We had plenty of time on our hands and stayed for dessert (tiramisu) which was lovely.  I'm looking forward to my next visit.
author: Lisa W.

description: My mom and I popped in this place while walking on Fillmore last night. I am super picky about my Italian so I will say it was good, but nothing special. You will find your typically antipasti (caldi and freddi), bread was average, but the service was great. Wine list needs some work particularly by the glass section. Gnocchi was decent and didn't get a chance to try dessert. Expect good but not extraordinary food.
author: Theresa T.

description: The prosciutto sandwich here was outstanding served with an ok side of salad.  Seems with the mediocre reviews here that the sandwich is a good option.  Also, a good price at right under $10.  I would go back just for the sandwich alone.
author: Adam B.

description: Great food, good wine.  And a nice atmosphere, and the regulars give it a nice community vibe.  My friend and I shared some risotte and gnocchi, with some anti-pasti.  It was all excellent, although the gnocchi was a tad chewy.  The wine was excellent.  I tend to lean towards French wine, but having the Italian house wine was a nice touch.
author: masa s.

description: This is my favorite Italian restaurant in my old neighborhood. Consistently great pasta (I typically get gnocchi) and the owners seem to know a lot of the (older) neighbors who come in so there's always a homey feel when I come here. They also have fabulous lemon cello so that's a must-have as your after-dinner drink. But I must confess the the real reason I come here is for their profiteroles...so rich, decadent and yums! I know - lemons and chocolate don't mix...but I make it work! :p
author: Nina R.

description:
It's almost impossible to find a place to grab a bite on Fillmore after 9:00 on a a Sunday night. We showed up around 9:45 and even though they were scheduled to close just a few minutes later, they were very accomodating. 

Skip the dry bread and save the carbs for the pasta. I was debating between the prawns and the spaghetti with prawns. The waiter suggested the latter and I took his advice, which turned out to be a mistake. It was inedibly boring and only had 4 shrimp, but the other people in my dinner party made better choices. Both the fettucine with eggplant and the gnocchi were delicious.
author: Cher E.

description: I was surprised to see the relatively low prices on the menu outside the door given that Via Veneto looks like a pretty upscale place. Well, let's just say you pay for what you get. I'd even say we overpaid for what we got - the food just wasn't that good - pretty bland and nothing very interesting in terms of ingredients or preparation. Probably won't go back.
author: Sydney L.

description: Good food, nice wine choice, will for sure be back.
author: Laurie K.

description: not the best italian ever. Nice names, but not so tasty.
author: armelle p.

description:
Several neighbors raved about Via, so my friend and I decided to give it a try one night (we live a block away.) Their speciality is a rendition of Venetian cuisine that's a little different than your typical Italian place. They have several veal, chicken, and seafood choices - but no beef, pork, game, etc.
The attitude of the hostess was snobby - but we're kind of used to this living in Pacific Heights.
We kept hearing about what a great value Via is. Well, that is all relative. Yes, it's reasonable for the neighborhood. However, it's not especially cheap for Italian. The appetizers are in the $10 range, pastas run about $15-$17, entrees around $20.
I had the clam and mussel appetizer in a simple white wine butter sauce. Excellent - some of the best I've had in SF. My friend had the Carpaccio and it was a HUGE disappointment. Yes, it's hard to imagine bad Carpaccio - but this tasted like it was shaved right off a frozen piece of beef. It had a disagreeable icy texture and bland flavor that really ruined what is usually a treat.
The pastas were very decent. They use a lot of garlic, which I don't consider a negative. I had a spaghetti with chopped , shrimp, and garlic in an olive oil sauce. My friend had the pasta with pancetta and ham in a tomato sauce. Both were flavorful and thankfully cooked perfectly al dente. The portions were sufficient, but on the smallish side for Italian. Without the appetizers we may have gone away hungry, which should never be the case in an Italian place! And especially at $15+ for pasta.The service was a bit rushed but acceptable. The decor seems like it was trying a little to hard to be "playful" and verged almost on tacky. The place was way too bright! The halogen lights made me feel like I was eating in a department store. The small space on Fillmore calls out for candles. Overall it was OK, but I wouldn't make a special trip if I didn't live in the neighborhood. The clam mussel appetizer and glass of wine would make a decent lunch
author: David C.

description: Just ate there for the first time and am looking forward to the next time.  Excellent food and wine.  The lobster ravioli with crab meat sauce was amazing.  Very large portions, reasonable prices.
author: Carolyn S.

description: Whenever I am in the city I always head for Via Veneto ~ Massimo greets you like family with a ready smile, and will accomodate your every wish. I have tried many things on the menu but I am always drawn toward their veal, no matter how it is prepared it is consistently delicious.
author: Trip C.

description: First and foremost, the service was outstanding.  The maitre'd offered us some bruschetta while waiting for our table and kept us constantly informed of our table's status.  The specials of the day were delicious, and the prices were pretty reasonable.  The staff was very friendly, professional, and knowledgeable.  They made the extra effort to connect with the customer.
author: Aggie R.

description: I really really like the fettucine alfredo here, hence the 4 star rating for that alone.  Others i have dined with have enjoyed their dishes as well. Its a very charming and quaint italian place, service is good.
author: Andrew G.

description: I've been going to Via Veneto for about ten years now and even worked as the hostess for about two and a half years.  It has been my restaurant of choice for every big birthday and graduation celebration as well as the more low-key evenings when I just want great food for a reasonable price.  The owner and staff are all very friendly and the food is incredible.  Whenever I'm in the mood for great italian food in a comfortable and inviting setting, Via is always my first choice!
author: Jessica H.

description: Food is tasty, service is comfortable, never rushed, easy to drop-in for a casual dinner that is consistently very good.
author: Howard R.

description:
pretty fantastic service, especially when it's less crowded (or you're the only younger customers)

the owner goes around and meets everyone, sometimes treats you a little, makes sure everyone's happy. very warm and cozy place :) very kind of old school, traditional italian

the food's pretty good too, but to be honest, we were so happy with the service, it didn't matter.
author: M M.

description:
I've been there twice-the first time it was decent.  Decent service, decent food, decent atmosphere.  That's why I give 2 stars.  But this last time it was absolutely awful-the place was clearly understaffed and the waiters rushing around in a panic ruined the atmosphere.  The service was horrendous.  We had to ask to order wine, ask to order an appetizer, and ask to order dinner-and we definitely waited a good 15 minutes in between each-we weren't in any rush.  The waiter i assume was one of the owners, since he stopped to give a pat on the back to each "regular" and offered everyone around us free limoncello at the end of their meals...except us.  Also, they never once refilled our water or our wine glasses.

The food was ok.  The bread wasn't warm.  The lobster ravioli seemed mushy-like a tuna fish consistency inside.  The linguine with seafood was completely average...and came with a stomachache.  The spinach salad was good, not the best I've had, but it was good.  Needless to say, we won't be going back.
author: Ashley M.

description: My sister and I decided on a whim to go here since we were starving after shopping on Fillmore. It looked nice and clean and the menu looked decent. I had some kind of chicken breast that was very dry, I couldn't finish it (don't remember what sis had, but she liked it more than mine). Also, service was insanely slow, and it wasn't even a busy night.  Won't be returning here.
author: Heather I.

description: Wow - I'm surprised I'm the first on this.  Via Veneto looks like most Fillmore digs, kinda snobby, full of fillmore crowd, and done up for people who like to look good but know nothing about food - it turns out that it's NOTHING like that at all.  Wear jeans and a polo or some T because you'll want to be comfy.  Everyone there is so nice and friendly and EVERYONE is local.  The food is good and the owner works almost every night to ensure quality control.  We went on a saturday night and only had to wait 15 minutes - they gave us complimentary bruschetta for our wait, and during the wait, we struck up conversation with those waiting with us.  After sitting, we were welcomed into two other tables conversations as all parties looked at each other's plates with envy and commented.  I sort of felt like I went with a group as the tables next to us would lean over and ask what we ordered, how it tasted, what we were doing later, etc.  It was a GREAT atmosphere, and I'd say a really easy and fun place to take a date.  Not too loud and not silent by any means.  The stuffed mushrooms were good but kinda small and at $8 for 6 caps, I'd pick a different appetizer.  The bruschetta was excellent with plenty to share for 2.  I'm still in search of a 1200 calorie cesar salad in this town, but Via's was closer to 200 using a fresh olive oil base - a very good spring salad version of a cesar but not my type - it was sorta Zuni Cafesque.  The linguine with clams was to die for in a light white wine and lemon sauce.  Our neighbors ordered the poched pear stuffed with vanilla ice cream in strawberry and creme fraiche sauce which, just for the description, sounded amazing.  No need for reservations!
author: Jared F.

description: Our family's favorite Italian restaurant for at least 15 years! Do not know why it is never in the Zagat Book!! Amazing, authentic Italian food, plus grilled specialties. No pizza. Involtini, eggplant rolled around mozzarel and topped with perfect marinara sauce a great appetizer. Via Veneto Sald, excellent. Penne Amatriciana, YUM!
author: Linda K.

description: Via Veneto is a very solid choice.  I live around the corner and go here all the time.  The food is great and the prices are reasonable.  Moreover, the service is very friendly.
author: Patrick D.

description: We entered Via Vento tonight at 5:30 and, given the early hour and the relative emptiness of the restaurant, were surprised when the greeter told us a table we asked for was "Reserved".   We are polite, well-dressed people and could see no logic in this: it seemed oddly  "random".  That was just the first sign we had innocently stumbled into the Twilight Zone to dine.  A man with a deafening air of stereotypyed  Italianness told us the specials.  One was crabmeat ravioli.  I selected that and a salad to follow.   He bulldozed me with "No!  Salad comes first", as if he were correcting some rube.  Of course in classic Italian cuisine, salad comes after the main course.  The appetizer comes first and is seldom something so ordinary as a small house salad.  But I felt myself in the presence of an overbearing ass, so---noblesse oblige--- just let him make my order HIS way.  (Made me yearn for my high school days dining at Burger King.  At least they knew how to do it MY way!)    Moments later a server arrived at the table to tell me "No crabmeat ravioli.  Porcini."  I changed my order to Chicken Sorrentino, a decent chicken dish.  My companion had chicken marsala, also okay.   Nothing, please believe me, nothing special here, though we had fun later laughing at the Bunuelian sequence of events, many not reported here, at Via Veneto.  Go for a laugh and no other reason.  The ghost of Rod Serling just may make an appearance.  If you happen to be a stoner, Via Veneto rates a must-do experience.  In summation: Feh!
author: x v.

description: I tried this place on a recommendation of a neighboring business, so I thought it HAD to be good, right?  Well...  I ordered the Mussels and Clams appetizer.  When the waiter set the bowl in front of me I got the distinct odor of fish!  Not the good kind!  That kind of shocked me and I looked at all of the shellfish carefully to make sure all were open, etc.  They were so I thought OK, let's try it.  The mussels were varying sizes, some were really BIG.  The clams were smallish.  And there was some definite grit going on.  The broth is what ruined the dish for me.  It just had an "off" flavor to it.  I usually like to dip my bread in it (which you have to because it is so tough!) and finish it off, but I couldn't.  Where was the garlic bread that usually comes with it at other places I've tried?  The mozzarella and tomato salad I ordered came WAY after the mussels and was served with olive oil and basil leaves.  I asked for balsamic vinegar because I prefer it that way.  The mozzarella was dry and the tomatoes appeared to be the hot house variety and had no flavor.  The balsamic was runny and weak tasting.  But the basil was good.  Fresh cracked pepper would have been nice also.  And I was surprised at how slow the service was considering they weren't even busy!  The host IS very friendly and nice, but I probably will not go back for the food which is a shame because I live only a few blocks away and I did meet a nice person to talk with while I ate. "-0
author: Paula W.

description: I couldn't rate the food, as we left after waiting 15 minutes at the bar, and couldn't even get someone to get us a drink, bread or an appetizer (after 3 tries).  The 'service' bordered somewhere between rude and dis-engaged, and there are far too many options for what I remember to be a pricey restaurant with only average Italian fare from a few years back.
author: Larry M.

description:
I was late, very late making dinner reservations for Valentines Day.  To my surprise, the gentleman who answered the phone at Via Veneto was more than accommodating with my dinner request for two.  After informing me that they were booked until 10PM he asked "When would you like to eat?"  I answered with 7:30 and he responded "How about 7:45?" OK!!!  
So... so far so good... but then we had to eat.  Upon arriving at the restaurant, it didn't appear to be that busy.  The menu was not fixed and was pleased to see several solid options.  I ordered the rib-eye (which I never would order unless at a steakhouse - but the waiter insisted it was their best item) and my date ordered the fish.  My rib-eye was overcooked and tough - her fish was dry and bland...  
Overall, the place itself is cute - staff is helpful - the meal was moderately priced... but I would have been happy to pay more for a decent meal.  I would pass on this one if you have an alternative.
author: Matt G.

description: This restaurant kept catching my eye since I'm a huge Italian food fan and well, I walk by it on my way to the bus everyday.  The menu seemed very reasonably priced so we finally decided to check it out last Friday night; just the two of us.  If it weren't for the service, I would have given this place 5 stars but just as many other Yelpers have said, this is where they're lacking.  As soon as we walked in, the host said he could seat us now, just give him a minute.  We weren't in any rush, so we stood there patiently with another group of 3.  Basically, there was a lot of going back and forth, more confusion and about 3 more "just a minute"s.  Again, we weren't in any hurry but we just wanted to know what was going on!  The group of 3 ended up leaving which caused the host to chase them down on the sidewalk and bring them back, only for them to continue waiting.  I don't know what was going on there but whatever, the host seated us a few minutes after that.  Our server greeted us and we asked to hear the specials...there were quite a few and I'm pretty sure they sounded awesome but they were rattled off so quickly, I wasn't able to catch most of them.  I would recommend they have a separate list of just specials since they have so many.  Anyways, I decided to give the basics a try: Bruschetta and the Fettuccine Alfredo (my fav food in the whole world).  Bruschetta was very decent and came with 6 pieces for $5!!!!  Amazing!  Usually, I pay around $7 for 3.  So I was eager to try my main dish.  I'd heard excellent things about the Fettuccine Alfredo here and it didn't disappoint!  Perfectly al dente, rich and creamy sauce, good consistency with a touch of nutmeg!  5 stars alone for this!  And only $10.50?!?!  Did I read that right?  YES!  Yes, I did!  Bottom line, I will be returning if only to enjoy that dish again...oooh, better idea...I'll get it to go.  I hope they do take-out!
author: Kelly H.

description: I had a late night dinner (9:30-10 pm) on a Wednesday night and have to say this was among my worst dining experiences. Nothing was right - the atmosphere was tense, the owner (or someone "in charge") was arguing with patrons, the service was really slow and the food itself was very disappointing. In my opinon, it's hard to do Italian poorly, but Via Veneto does. I will never go back there again.
author: c c.

description: This place is amazing. And I'm not just talking about the hospitality you recieve from the moment you enter the threshold of this authentic and charming nook. I love all the collector magnum bottles of wine around the kitchen... talk about gettin' a party started! Seriously though, the wine list is very impressive.  Every dish I have tried is delicious.  Lobster ravioli is so good, as is the scaloppine de funghetto. GREAT date spot. I also really enjoy the intriguing murals on the walls. Mossimo and the entire team at Via Veneto are top notch and they will make you and your stomach very happy :)
author: Zachary D.

description: My gal-pal and I went here for dunch (that is, a late lunch that becomes dinner) on a Saturday after strolling about the Marina and Pac Heights.  Based on appearance and the vast menu of Italian faves like calamari, scallopine, and marsala, Via Veneto looked like it could be a winner and at 5pm we knew we would receive impeccable service.  The ambiance is charming...green vines and faux frescoes.  There is also a quaint patio in the back for those sunnier days. The house red was great...Montepulciano. ummmmm.  We shared a half carafe for $11.  What a deal!  I sensed it was going to be a good meal by the freshness of the table bread and whole roasted garlic clove-infused oil.  We started with the beef carpaccio.  Paper thin quality beef served w/ oo, capers, parm, and lemon wedges.  Tasssssty!  My dunch-mate ordered the gnocci with gorgonzola cream sauce and I ate like an animal.  I went from raw beef to a big fat pork chop.  (hey-i need my protein).  It was one of the specials...pork chop stuffed with prosciutto and gorgonzola served with mixed veg and roasted potatoes.  This was one tasty hunk of meat and I'll have to admit the veggies weren't mixed, but the veggie sure was good.  We think it was chard, but I forgot to ask.  My gal-pal said the gnocci was authentic and scrumptuous.  We talked our way well into the dinner rush and finally dessert.  What's an Italian dinner without the Tiramisu?  Man, am i glad we splurged.  It wasn't too soggy, nor to creamy, it was just right and the fresh raspberries were the perfect touch. Wine, premium app, two entrees, and dessert...for $60.  That is a serious steal for a quality meal in SF and even more so in Pac Heights.
author: Regan P.

description: I love this place (obviously others tend not to agree)!  They have an awesome special of lobster ravioli which you can order when it's not even on the menu.  The service is great if you want a chilll meal (not if you're in a rush).  Massimo was very friendly with great wine suggestions.  I recommend the poached pear for dessert!  A great meal!
author: Jaclyn M.

description: Great service, wonderful menu (I had their veal), and definitely personalized service.  My girfriends and I had a wonderful dinner at Via Veneto and I have been wanting to take my husband there for quite some time.  Highly recommended.
author: Tarina T.

description: This place is great for a group/family dinner. The staff are very friendly and the place feels genuinely Italian. The waiter was quick to take our order and there is a good selection of wines and main courses to choose from. The stuffed mushrooms and bruscetta were really tasty, very fresh tomatoes and nicely toasted bread. Everyone enjoyed the main courses, with the lobster ravioli and sea bass being the stand out dishes. Overall, we had a really enjoyable dinner - the service was great and while the food isn't anything that will blow you away, it's simple and tasty - just how Italian food should be. If there's anything negative at all, the decor and lighting is too bright for me so if you're looking for a super trendy place or a cozy romantic restaurant, this isn't it. But if you're looking for a friendly Italian spot with good food then you should definitely consider going here.
author: Andy F.

description: if i have to start with the flecks of something floating around in my water glass then,so be it. i started to say something to the waiter but i noticed that anna and adrienne also had them in their glass so i just chalked it up to authentic italian water.  the oil and garlic that they serve up with their bread made me feel greasy. and not in a good,i just got laid kinda way. i'd ask if you 'feel me' but thats a tangent thats best for another forum.  i ordered the bruschetta.pasta pomodoro makes it better.sadly. i got the potato gnocchi with gorgonzola sauce. it was decent. it didnt stick to my teeth. the sauce was nice. the service was kind of (really)slow. our waiter who may have been massimo kept looking and talking to other tables while he was taking our order.im pretty boring. and i look like rocky from mask so i can understand the reluctance to look at me but hey, i got money now. and im ordering food in your establishment. maybe if i took my panties off i would have gotten better service? anna's food looked like i might have made it. and im no cook.adrienne's pasta tasted okay. nothing special.lots of old people and people who didnt want to wait anywhere else (like us). the profiteroles were soggy and i think someone may have sucked the custard out of the ones we ordered.  we had to get the check from the water guy. it looks like alot of people like this place. i dont get it. and i hope its not contagious.
author: Jim M.
